lure.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to persuade someone to do something, especially something wrong or dangerous, by making it seem attractive or exciting
lure.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: People may be lured into buying tickets by clever advertising.
Computer games are luring youngsters away from their lessons.
lure.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to attract customers, workers, money etc from another company or place
lure.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: The bank launched an advertising campaign to lure back its traditional customers.
It’s very difficult to lure talent away from Silicon Valley.
lure.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: something that attracts people, or the quality of being able to do this
lure.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: Malc wasn’t mature enough to resist the lure of drink and drugs.
lure.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: an object used to attract animals or fish so that they can be caught
lure.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: to attract customers, workers, money etc from another company or place, especially by making a product, service, or job sound very exciting, profitable etc
lure.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: Even with Oscar nominations to lure audiences, the films will face tough competition over the next few weeks from new releases.
The company lured a Japanese executive away from Toshiba Corp. to run its Tokyo operations.
